dek: Only in Scandinavia—where every design is thought about and carefully art-directed—would the lowly rest stop get the starchitect treatment.

items.caption: Norway is halfway through an 18-year plan to spruce up its motorways with roadside overlooks, art installations, and architectural walkways that put American rest stops to shame. It has already built 120 like Steilneset (pictured), which is located in Vardo, at the edge of the Barents Sea in the country’s far north. The result of a collaboration between Pritzker Prize–winning architect Peter Zumthor and the late, great artist Louise Bourgeois, the work commemorates the victims of Vardo’s early-seventeenth-century witch trials. Here, Zumthor’s “forest” of wooden supports is bisected by a long surfboard-shaped structure. Then walk along the rugged coastline and you’ll arrive at a glass-and-steel structure housing Bourgeois’s haunting installation: a schoolhouse chair with flames jetting out of the seat, encircled by a halo of seven giant mirrors. Not all the installations are so somber: Read on for a dreamy drive through the country’s best new lookouts.

**Stop 1: Steilneset**










Architect Peter Zumthor constructed this Steilneset pavilion at Norway’s northern edge, in remembrance of the victims of the Vardo area’s seventeenth-century witch trials: Almost 100 people were executed between 1598 and 1692.

items.title: Stop 1: Steilneset
items.caption: Artist Louise Bourgeois’s Steilneset installation, also dedicated to the witch-trial victims and on the same site as Zumthor’s work in northern Norway, has a central chair with five flames jetting from the seat. It’s encased in a black-glass cube; in winter, the flames contrast with the icy Nordic surrounds.

items.title: Stop 2: Bergsbotn
items.caption:
**See**: On a rocky bluff overlooking a canyon, lush forests, and snowcapped mountains, this cantilevered wood-and-steel bridge offers an ideal photo op—especially when the viewing platform sways in the wind.





**Stay**: Hamn i Senja is a waterfront retreat offering dogsledding, snowshoeing, and sublime seafood (47-778-59880; doubles from $196).

items.title: Stop 2: Bergsbotn
items.caption: This runway-like viewing platform, called Bergsbotn, is flanked by verdant mountains and looks to the Bergsfjord in the ocean off northern Norway.

items.title: Stop 3: Eggum
items.caption:
**See**: Built into the fort-like ruins of Borga’s World War II radar station at the foot of a grassy coastal mountain, this oversized box is made from local driftwood that mimics the landscape’s earthy hues. Take a walk on the adjacent beach, or picnic at a table in the structure’s outdoor amphitheater.





**Stay**: The seaside hideaway resort Henningsvær Bryggehotell (47-760-74750; doubles from $260).

items.title: Stop 3: Eggum
items.caption: Eggum’s simple box design by the Snøhetta architectural team is made from driftwood set into an old quarry on a peninsula in Norway’s northern half.

items.title: Stop 4: Hellåga
items.caption:
**See**: The Sjonafjord, a thing of pure Nordic beauty: Its still water is dotted with icy islands and backdropped by the massive Svartisen Glacier. See it from this waterside pavilion, then take stairs to the sea to soak in another perspective.





**Stay**: Mo i Rana’s nineteenth-century Meyergården Hotell. Try the reindeer stew (47-751-34000; doubles from $286).

items.title: Stop 5: Askevågen
items.caption:
**See**: A glass sheet is all that separates you from the frigid ocean at this viewing platform along the famed Atlantic Road. Buy a grill from the nearest gas station and fire up fresh catch while you savor the scenery.





**Eat**: Duck into the nearby Bjartmars Favorittkro restaurant for salt cod served in a cozy water-view dining room (Atlantic Rd., Averøy; 47-715-16060; entrées from $39).

items.title: Stop 5: Askevågen
items.caption: Askevågen is a minimalist viewing platform at the end of a breakwater on the side of Norway’s famed Atlantic Road.

items.title: Stop 6: Sohlbergplassen
items.caption:
**See**: If you stand at the lookout point of this elevated concrete pathway and face Atnsjøen Lake and the mountains, you’re in the spot where Harald Sohlberg painted Winter Night in the Mountains in 1914. The other raised trails wind through the trees of Rondane


National Park.





**Stay**: Rondane Gjestegård is a rustically charming inn known for waffles and homemade jam (47-624-63720; doubles, $156).

items.title: Stop 6: Sohlbergplassen
items.caption: Norwegian architect Carl-Viggo Hølmebakk designed the curvy elevated paths, called Sohlbergplassen, that run through the trees of central Norway’s Rondane National Park.

items.title: Stop 7: Svandalsfossen
items.caption:
**See**: This sleek metal construction, leading up the Svandalsfossen waterfall and down to the Lyse­fjord, has nearly 500 stairs. Climb them, then wander the town of Sauda, known for its nineteenth-century zinc mines.





**Stay**: Get a sixties flashback at Nes­flaten’s Energihotellet, a former power station that now has mid-­century modern decor and spectacular views (47-512-00555; doubles, $178).
